sn35.248:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose a sheaf of barley was placed at a crossroads.

sn35.248:1.2.eng: Then six people would come along carrying flails,

sn35.248:1.3.eng: and start threshing the sheaf of barley.

sn35.248:1.4.pli: Evañhi sā, bhikkhave, yavakalāpī suhatā assa chahi byābhaṅgīhi haññamānā.
sn35.248:1.4.eng: So that sheaf of barley would be thoroughly threshed by those six flails.

sn35.248:1.5.eng: Then a seventh individual would come along carrying a flail,

sn35.248:1.6.pli: So taṃ yavakalāpiṃ sattamāya byābhaṅgiyā haneyya.
sn35.248:1.6.eng: and they’d give the sheaf of barley a seventh threshing.

sn35.248:1.7.pli: Evañhi sā bhikkhave, yavakalāpī suhatatarā assa, sattamāya byābhaṅgiyā haññamānā.
sn35.248:1.7.eng: So that sheaf of barley would be even more thoroughly threshed by that seventh flail.

sn35.248:1.8.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano cakkhusmiṃ haññati manāpāmanāpehi rūpehi …pe…
sn35.248:1.8.eng: In the same way, an unlearned ordinary person is struck in the eye by both pleasant and unpleasant sights.

sn35.248:1.9.eng: They’re struck in the ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.248:1.10.eng: mind by both pleasant and unpleasant ideas.

sn35.248:1.11.pli: Sace so, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano āyatiṃ punabbhavāya ceteti, evañhi so, bhikkhave, moghapuriso suhatataro hoti, seyyathāpi sā yavakalāpī sattamāya byābhaṅgiyā haññamānā.
sn35.248:1.11.eng: And if that unlearned ordinary person intends to be reborn in a new state of existence in the future, that futile person is even more thoroughly struck, like that sheaf of barley threshed by the seventh person.

sn35.248:2.1.eng: Once upon a time, a battle was fought between the gods and the titans.
sn35.248:2.1.comm: This war goes on so long as day replaces night (SN 11.1:2.1).

sn35.248:2.2.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo asure āmantesi:
sn35.248:2.2.eng: Then Vepacitti, lord of titans, addressed the titans,

sn35.248:2.3.pli: ‘sace, mārisā, devāsurasaṅgāme samupabyūḷhe asurā jineyyuṃ devā parājineyyuṃ, yena naṃ sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ kaṇṭhapañcamehi bandhanehi bandhitvā mama santike āneyyātha asurapuran’ti.
sn35.248:2.3.eng: ‘My good fellows, if the titans defeat the gods in this battle, bind Sakka, the lord of gods, by his limbs and neck and bring him to my presence in the citadel of the titans.’

sn35.248:2.4.pli: Sakkopi kho, bhikkhave, devānamindo deve tāvatiṃse āmantesi:
sn35.248:2.4.eng: Meanwhile, Sakka, lord of gods, addressed the gods of the thirty-three,

sn35.248:2.5.pli: ‘sace, mārisā, devāsurasaṅgāme samupabyūḷhe devā jineyyuṃ asurā parājineyyuṃ, yena naṃ vepacittiṃ asurindaṃ kaṇṭhapañcamehi bandhanehi bandhitvā mama santike āneyyātha sudhammaṃ devasabhan’ti.
sn35.248:2.5.eng: ‘My good fellows, if the gods defeat the titans in this battle, bind Vepacitti by his limbs and neck and bring him to my presence in the Hall of Clear Right of the gods.’

sn35.248:2.6.pli: Tasmiṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, saṅgāme devā jiniṃsu, asurā parājiniṃsu.
sn35.248:2.6.eng: In that battle the gods won and the titans lost.

sn35.248:2.7.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, devā tāvatiṃsā vepacittiṃ asurindaṃ kaṇṭhapañcamehi bandhanehi bandhitvā sakkassa devānamindassa santike ānesuṃ sudhammaṃ devasabhaṃ.
sn35.248:2.7.eng: So the gods of the thirty-three bound Vepacitti by his limbs and neck and brought him to Sakka’s presence in the Hall of Clear Right of the gods.

sn35.248:2.8.pli: Tatra sudaṃ, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo kaṇṭhapañcamehi bandhanehi baddho hoti.
sn35.248:2.8.eng: And there Vepacitti remained bound by his limbs and neck.

sn35.248:2.9.pli: Yadā kho, bhikkhave, vepacittissa asurindassa evaṃ hoti:

sn35.248:2.10.pli: ‘dhammikā kho devā, adhammikā asurā, idheva dānāhaṃ devapuraṃ gacchāmī’ti.
sn35.248:2.10.eng: ‘It’s the gods who are principled, while the titans are unprincipled. Now I belong right here in the castle of the gods.’

sn35.248:2.11.pli: Atha kaṇṭhapañcamehi bandhanehi muttaṃ attānaṃ samanupassati, dibbehi ca pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti.
sn35.248:2.11.eng: Then he found himself freed from the bonds on his limbs and neck. He entertained himself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of heavenly sensual stimulation.

sn35.248:2.12.pli: Yadā ca kho, bhikkhave, vepacittissa asurindassa evaṃ hoti:

sn35.248:2.13.pli: ‘dhammikā kho asurā, adhammikā devā, tattheva dānāhaṃ asurapuraṃ gamissāmī’ti.
sn35.248:2.13.eng: ‘It’s the titans who are principled, while the gods are unprincipled. Now I will go over there to the citadel of the titans,’

sn35.248:2.14.pli: atha kaṇṭhapañcamehi bandhanehi baddhaṃ attānaṃ samanupassati, dibbehi ca pañcahi kāmaguṇehi parihāyati.
sn35.248:2.14.eng: he found himself bound by his limbs and neck, and the five kinds of heavenly sensual stimulation fell away.

sn35.248:2.15.eng: That’s how subtly Vepacitti was bound.

sn35.248:2.16.eng: But the bonds of Māra are even more subtle than that.

sn35.248:2.17.pli: Maññamāno kho, bhikkhave, baddho mārassa, amaññamāno mutto pāpimato.
sn35.248:2.17.eng: When you conceive, you’re bound by Māra. Not conceiving, you’re free from the Wicked One.

sn35.248:3.1.pli: ‘Asmī’ti, bhikkhave, maññitametaṃ, ‘ayamahamasmī’ti maññitametaṃ, ‘bhavissan’ti maññitametaṃ, ‘na bhavissan’ti maññitametaṃ, ‘rūpī bhavissan’ti maññitametaṃ, ‘arūpī bhavissan’ti maññitametaṃ, ‘saññī bhavissan’ti maññitametaṃ, ‘asaññī bhavissan’ti maññitametaṃ, ‘nevasaññīnāsaññī bhavissan’ti maññitametaṃ.
sn35.248:3.1.eng: These are what is conceived: ‘I am’, ‘I am this’, ‘I will be’, ‘I will not be’, ‘I will have form’, ‘I will be formless’, ‘I will be percipient’, ‘I will be non-percipient’, ‘I will be neither percipient nor non-percipient.’

sn35.248:3.2.pli: Maññitaṃ, bhikkhave, rogo, maññitaṃ gaṇḍo, maññitaṃ sallaṃ.
sn35.248:3.2.eng: What is conceived is a disease, a boil, a dart.

sn35.248:3.3.eng: So mendicants, you should train yourselves like this: ‘We will live with a heart that does not conceive.’

sn35.248:4.1.pli: ‘Asmī’ti, bhikkhave, iñjitametaṃ, ‘ayamahamasmī’ti iñjitametaṃ, ‘bhavissan’ti iñjitametaṃ, ‘na bhavissan’ti iñjitametaṃ, ‘rūpī bhavissan’ti iñjitametaṃ, ‘arūpī bhavissan’ti iñjitametaṃ, ‘saññī bhavissan’ti iñjitametaṃ, ‘asaññī bhavissan’ti iñjitametaṃ, ‘nevasaññīnāsaññī bhavissan’ti iñjitametaṃ.
sn35.248:4.1.eng: These are what is perturbed: ‘I am’, ‘I am this’, ‘I will be’, ‘I will not be’, ‘I will have form’, ‘I will be formless’, ‘I will be percipient’, ‘I will be non-percipient’, ‘I will be neither percipient nor non-percipient.’
sn35.248:4.1.comm: Such thoughts arise when the mind is perturbed; the same method applies to the following terms.

sn35.248:4.2.pli: Iñjitaṃ, bhikkhave, rogo, iñjitaṃ gaṇḍo, iñjitaṃ sallaṃ.
sn35.248:4.2.eng: What is perturbed is a disease, a boil, a dart.

sn35.248:4.3.eng: So mendicants, you should train yourselves like this: ‘We will live with a heart free of perturbation.’

sn35.248:5.1.pli: ‘Asmī’ti, bhikkhave, phanditametaṃ, ‘ayamahamasmī’ti phanditametaṃ, ‘bhavissan’ti …pe… ‘na bhavissan’ti … ‘rūpī bhavissan’ti … ‘arūpī bhavissan’ti … ‘saññī bhavissan’ti … ‘asaññī bhavissan’ti … ‘nevasaññīnāsaññī bhavissan’ti phanditametaṃ.
sn35.248:5.1.eng: These are what is trembled: ‘I am’, ‘I am this’, ‘I will be’, ‘I will not be’, ‘I will have form’, ‘I will be formless’, ‘I will be percipient’, ‘I will be non-percipient’, ‘I will be neither percipient nor non-percipient.’

sn35.248:5.2.pli: Phanditaṃ, bhikkhave, rogo, phanditaṃ gaṇḍo, phanditaṃ sallaṃ.
sn35.248:5.2.eng: What is trembled is a disease, a boil, a dart.

sn35.248:5.3.eng: So mendicants, you should train yourselves like this: ‘We will live with a heart free of trembling.’

sn35.248:6.1.pli: ‘Asmī’ti, bhikkhave, papañcitametaṃ, ‘ayamahamasmī’ti papañcitametaṃ, ‘bhavissan’ti …pe… ‘na bhavissan’ti … ‘rūpī bhavissan’ti … ‘arūpī bhavissan’ti … ‘saññī bhavissan’ti … ‘asaññī bhavissan’ti … ‘nevasaññīnāsaññī bhavissan’ti papañcitametaṃ.
sn35.248:6.1.eng: These are what is proliferated: ‘I am’, ‘I am this’, ‘I will be’, ‘I will not be’, ‘I will have form’, ‘I will be formless’, ‘I will be percipient’, ‘I will be non-percipient’, ‘I will be neither percipient nor non-percipient.’

sn35.248:6.2.pli: Papañcitaṃ, bhikkhave, rogo, papañcitaṃ gaṇḍo, papañcitaṃ sallaṃ.
sn35.248:6.2.eng: What is proliferated is a disease, a boil, a dart.

sn35.248:6.3.eng: So mendicants, you should train yourselves like this: ‘We will live with a heart free of proliferation.’

sn35.248:7.1.pli: ‘Asmī’ti, bhikkhave, mānagatametaṃ, ‘ayamahamasmī’ti mānagatametaṃ, ‘bhavissan’ti mānagatametaṃ, ‘na bhavissan’ti mānagatametaṃ, ‘rūpī bhavissan’ti mānagatametaṃ, ‘arūpī bhavissan’ti mānagatametaṃ, ‘saññī bhavissan’ti mānagatametaṃ, ‘asaññī bhavissan’ti mānagatametaṃ, ‘nevasaññīnāsaññī bhavissan’ti mānagatametaṃ.
sn35.248:7.1.eng: These are states of conceit: ‘I am’, ‘I am this’, ‘I will be’, ‘I will not be’, ‘I will have form’, ‘I will be formless’, ‘I will be percipient’, ‘I will be non-percipient’, ‘I will be neither percipient nor non-percipient.’
sn35.248:7.1.comm: A “state of conceit” (mānagata) is conceit that has been solidified into a view.

sn35.248:7.2.pli: Mānagataṃ, bhikkhave, rogo, mānagataṃ gaṇḍo, mānagataṃ sallaṃ.
sn35.248:7.2.eng: The state of conceit is a disease, a boil, a dart.

sn35.248:7.3.eng: So mendicants, you should train yourselves like this: ‘We will live with a heart that has struck down conceit.’”

sn35.248:9.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on the six sense fields are complete.

sn35.25:0.3.eng: Giving Up By Direct Knowledge and Complete Understanding

sn35.25:1.1.pli: “Sabbaṃ abhiññā pariññā pahānāya vo, bhikkhave, dhammaṃ desessāmi.
sn35.25:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the principle for giving up the all by direct knowledge and complete understanding.

sn35.25:1.3.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, sabbaṃ abhiññā pariññā pahānāya dhammo?
sn35.25:1.3.eng: And what is the principle for giving up the all by direct knowledge and complete understanding?

sn35.25:1.4.pli: Cakkhuṃ, bhikkhave, abhiññā pariññā pahātabbaṃ, rūpā abhiññā pariññā pahātabbā, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ abhiññā pariññā pahātabbaṃ, cakkhusamphasso abhiññā pariññā pahātabbo, yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi abhiññā pariññā pahātabbaṃ …pe…
sn35.25:1.4.eng: The eye should be given up by direct knowledge and complete understanding. Sights should be given up by direct knowledge and complete understanding. Eye consciousness should be given up by direct knowledge and complete understanding. Eye contact should be given up by direct knowledge and complete understanding. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact should be given up by direct knowledge and complete understanding.

sn35.25:1.6.pli: jivhā abhiññā pariññā pahātabbā, rasā abhiññā pariññā pahātabbā, jivhāviññāṇaṃ abhiññā pariññā pahātabbaṃ, jivhāsamphasso abhiññā pariññā pahātabbo, yampidaṃ jivhāsamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi abhiññā pariññā pahātabbaṃ.

sn35.25:1.8.pli: mano abhiññā pariññā pahātabbo, dhammā abhiññā pariññā pahātabbā, manoviññāṇaṃ abhiññā pariññā pahātabbaṃ, manosamphasso abhiññā pariññā pahātabbo, yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi abhiññā pariññā pahātabbaṃ.
sn35.25:1.8.eng: mind should be given up by direct knowledge and complete understanding. Ideas should be given up by direct knowledge and complete understanding. Mind consciousness should be given up by direct knowledge and complete understanding. Mind contact should be given up by direct knowledge and complete understanding. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact should be given up by direct knowledge and complete understanding.

sn35.25:1.9.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sabbaṃ abhiññā pariññā pahānāya dhammo”ti.
sn35.25:1.9.eng: This is the principle for giving up the all by direct knowledge and complete understanding.”

sn35.26:1.1.pli: “Sabbaṃ, bhikkhave, anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.26:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, without directly knowing and completely understanding the all, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.

sn35.26:1.2.pli: Kiñca, bhikkhave, anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya?
sn35.26:1.2.eng: And what is the all, without directly knowing and completely understanding which, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering?
sn35.26:1.2.comm: MS edition omits sabbaṁ by mistake; it is found in PTS and BJT editions, and is included in the mirror passage below (SN 35.26:2.2).

sn35.26:1.3.pli: Cakkhuṃ, bhikkhave, anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.26:1.3.eng: Without directly knowing and completely understanding the eye, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.

sn35.26:1.4.pli: Rūpe anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.26:1.4.eng: Without directly knowing and completely understanding sights …

sn35.26:1.5.pli: Cakkhuviññāṇaṃ anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.

sn35.26:1.6.pli: Cakkhusamphassaṃ anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.

sn35.26:1.7.pli: Yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya …pe…
sn35.26:1.7.eng: painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.

sn35.26:1.8.pli: jivhaṃ anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.26:1.8.eng: Without directly knowing and completely understanding the ear … the nose … the tongue …

sn35.26:1.12.pli: yampidaṃ jivhāsamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.

sn35.26:1.14.pli: manaṃ anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.26:1.14.eng: the mind, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.

sn35.26:1.15.eng: Without directly knowing and completely understanding ideas …

sn35.26:1.18.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.26:1.18.eng: painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.

sn35.26:1.19.pli: Idaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sabbaṃ anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.26:1.19.eng: This is the all, without directly knowing and completely understanding which, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.

sn35.26:2.1.pli: Sabbañca kho, bhikkhave, abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.26:2.1.eng: By directly knowing and completely understanding the all, having dispassion for it and giving it up, you can end suffering.

sn35.26:2.2.pli: Kiñca, bhikkhave, sabbaṃ abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāya?
sn35.26:2.2.eng: And what is the all, directly knowing and completely understanding which, having dispassion for it and giving it up, you can end suffering?

sn35.26:2.3.pli: Cakkhuṃ, bhikkhave, abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.26:2.3.eng: By directly knowing and completely understanding the eye …

sn35.26:2.4.pli: Rūpe abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.

sn35.26:2.5.pli: Cakkhuviññāṇaṃ abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.

sn35.26:2.6.pli: Cakkhusamphassaṃ abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.

sn35.26:2.7.pli: Yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāya …pe…

sn35.26:2.8.pli: jivhaṃ abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.26:2.8.eng: the ear … the nose … the tongue …

sn35.26:2.12.pli: yampidaṃ jivhāsamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.

sn35.26:2.14.pli: manaṃ abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.26:2.14.eng: the mind, having dispassion for it and giving it up, you can end suffering.

sn35.26:2.15.eng: By directly knowing and completely understanding ideas …

sn35.26:2.18.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.26:2.18.eng: painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact, having dispassion for it and giving it up, you can end suffering.

sn35.26:2.19.pli: Idaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sabbaṃ abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāyā”ti.
sn35.26:2.19.eng: This is the all, directly knowing and completely understanding which, having dispassion for it and giving it up, you can end suffering.”

sn35.27:1.1.pli: “Sabbaṃ, bhikkhave, anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.27:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, without directly knowing and completely understanding the all, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.

sn35.27:1.2.pli: Kiñca, bhikkhave, sabbaṃ anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya?
sn35.27:1.2.eng: And what is the all, without directly knowing and completely understanding which, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering?

sn35.27:1.3.pli: Yañca, bhikkhave, cakkhu, ye ca rūpā, yañca cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, ye ca cakkhuviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā …pe…
sn35.27:1.3.eng: The eye, sights, eye consciousness, and things knowable by eye consciousness.
sn35.27:1.3.comm: The phrase “eye, sights, eye consciousness, and things knowable by eye consciousness” appears redundant, as “sights” (rūpa) are precisely what is “knowable by eye consciousness”. Where the phrase occurs elsewhere, rūpa may appear (MN 112:10.2, SN 35.65:2.1, SN 35.68:1.3) or it may not (MN 144:9.1, SN 35.87:7.1). Bodhi summarizes the commentary’s explanations, which he describes as “contrived” (Middle Length Discourses, note 1080, and Connected Discourses note 12 on book 4). At least one Chinese parallel omits rūpa here, thus avoiding the redundancy (MA 187 at T i 732c19). It is likely the original passage did not include rūpa and it was added in an old editorial oversight.

sn35.27:1.4.pli: yā ca jivhā, ye ca rasā, yañca jivhāviññāṇaṃ, ye ca jivhāviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā;

sn35.27:1.5.pli: yo ca kāyo, ye ca phoṭṭhabbā, yañca kāyaviññāṇaṃ, ye ca kāyaviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā;

sn35.27:1.6.pli: yo ca mano, ye ca dhammā, yañca manoviññāṇaṃ, ye ca manoviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā—
sn35.27:1.6.eng: The mind, ideas, mind consciousness, and things knowable by mind consciousness.

sn35.27:1.7.pli: idaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sabbaṃ anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.27:1.7.eng: This is the all, without directly knowing and completely understanding which, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.

sn35.27:2.1.pli: Sabbaṃ, bhikkhave, abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn35.27:2.1.eng: By directly knowing and completely understanding the all, having dispassion for it and giving it up, you can end suffering.

sn35.27:2.2.pli: Kiñca, bhikkhave, sabbaṃ abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāya?
sn35.27:2.2.eng: And what is the all, directly knowing and completely understanding which, having dispassion for it and giving it up, you can end suffering?

sn35.27:2.3.pli: Yañca, bhikkhave, cakkhu, ye ca rūpā, yañca cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, ye ca cakkhuviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā …pe…
sn35.27:2.3.eng: The eye, sights, eye consciousness, and things knowable by eye consciousness.

sn35.27:2.4.pli: yā ca jivhā, ye ca rasā, yañca jivhāviññāṇaṃ, ye ca jivhāviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā;

sn35.27:2.5.pli: yo ca kāyo, ye ca phoṭṭhabbā, yañca kāyaviññāṇaṃ, ye ca kāyaviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā;

sn35.27:2.6.pli: yo ca mano, ye ca dhammā, yañca manoviññāṇaṃ, ye ca manoviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā—
sn35.27:2.6.eng: The mind, ideas, mind consciousness, and things knowable by mind consciousness.

sn35.27:2.7.pli: idaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sabbaṃ abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāyā”ti.
sn35.27:2.7.eng: This is the all, directly knowing and completely understanding which, having dispassion for it and giving it up, you can end suffering.”

sn35.28:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā gayāyaṃ viharati gayāsīse saddhiṃ bhikkhusahassena.
sn35.28:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Gayā on Gayā Head together with a thousand mendicants.
sn35.28:1.1.comm: This is the famous “third sermon”. After the Buddha’s awakening at Uruvelā, he went to Varanasi to teach the five mendicants (SN 56.11), then returned to Uruvelā, where he stayed with and ultimately converted a community of dreadlocked fire-worshiping ascetics led by three Kassapa brothers. The elaborate narrative prominently features the ascetics’ reverence for fire, over which the Buddha wielded mastery. They took ordination, then he taught this discourse (Kd 1:15.1.1).

sn35.28:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

sn35.28:1.3.comm: The Buddha starts with the uncommon term āditta, which refers to a current state (“is burning”, “has been set of fire”), avoiding the use of aggi (Sanskrit agni), which would evoke the deity of that name. | References to agni, to sarva (“all”), and to Agni as all, are legion in Vedic texts. Since all sacrifices are Agni (4.5.1.13), Agni is all the gods (1.6.2.8, 3.1.3.1, 3.4.1.19, 4.6.3.2), or is the Self of all the gods (14.3.2.5). Fire consumes all, so all food is of Agni (10.1.4.13). But the direct inspiration for this discourse is probably the famous “Honey Lore”. Situated just after the revelation that the true Self is infinite consciousness, this passage identifies all aspects of being, including fire, as “honey”, since they partake of the immortal, the divine, and the “all” (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.5). Likewise, after his teaching that the aggregates, including all forms of consciousness, are “not self” (SN 22.59), the Buddha inverts the message of the Honey Lore, pointing out that “all” we experience is on fire.

sn35.28:1.4.eng: And what is the all that is burning?

sn35.28:1.5.pli: Cakkhu, bhikkhave, ādittaṃ, rūpā ādittā, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ ādittaṃ, cakkhusamphasso āditto. Yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi ādittaṃ.
sn35.28:1.5.eng: The eye is burning. Sights are burning. Eye consciousness is burning. Eye contact is burning. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact is also burning.

sn35.28:1.6.comm: Or perhaps, “Set on fire by what?”

sn35.28:1.7.pli: ‘Rāgagginā, dosagginā, mohagginā ādittaṃ, jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi ādittan’ti vadāmi …pe…
sn35.28:1.7.eng: Burning with the fires of greed, hate, and delusion. Burning with rebirth, old age, and death, with sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn35.28:1.7.comm: These “three fires” are also at AN 7.47 and Iti 93. | Only after establishing that the senses are “burning” does the Buddha complete his inversion of Vedic values: it is fire itself which, far from being a benevolent deity, is aflame with greed, hate, and delusion. This had to wait until the Buddha was sure in his students, for it has the unpalatable implication that the god himself is subject to such flaws. After all, the ritual is performed with verses of desire (chandas) in order to secure worldly prosperity (Snp 1.2) or an eternity in heaven (SN 42.6:2.1); it is carried out by means of sacrificial violence (MN 51:10.7, AN 4.39, SN 3.9); and it is based on a delusional way of seeing the world, the blind leading the blind (MN 95:13.23).

sn35.28:1.8.pli: jivhā ādittā, rasā ādittā, jivhāviññāṇaṃ ādittaṃ, jivhāsamphasso āditto. Yampidaṃ jivhāsamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi ādittaṃ.

sn35.28:1.10.pli: ‘Rāgagginā, dosagginā, mohagginā ādittaṃ, jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi ādittan’ti vadāmi …pe…

sn35.28:1.11.pli: mano āditto, dhammā ādittā, manoviññāṇaṃ ādittaṃ, manosamphasso āditto. Yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi ādittaṃ.
sn35.28:1.11.eng: The mind is burning. Ideas are burning. Mind consciousness is burning. Mind contact is burning. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact is also burning.

sn35.28:1.13.pli: ‘Rāgagginā, dosagginā, mohagginā ādittaṃ, jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi ādittan’ti vadāmi.
sn35.28:1.13.eng: Burning with the fires of greed, hate, and delusion. Burning with rebirth, old age, and death, with sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress, I say.

sn35.28:1.14.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati, rūpesupi nibbindati, cakkhuviññāṇepi nibbindati, cakkhusamphassepi nibbindati, yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tasmimpi nibbindati …pe…
sn35.28:1.14.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact. And they grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact.

sn35.28:1.15.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tasmimpi nibbindati.
sn35.28:1.15.eng: They grow disillusioned with the ear … nose … tongue … body … mind … painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact.

sn35.28:1.16.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn35.28:1.16.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn35.28:1.17.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn35.28:1.17.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn35.28:2.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn35.28:2.2.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanduṃ.
sn35.28:2.2.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

sn35.28:2.3.pli: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne tassa bhikkhusahassassa anupādāya āsavehi cittāni vimucciṃsūti.
sn35.28:2.3.eng: And while this discourse was being spoken, the minds of the thousand mendicants were freed from defilements by not grasping.

sn35.29:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn35.29:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn35.29:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

sn35.29:1.4.comm: Here “overcome” (addhabhūta), like āditta in the previous discourse, is a term for suffering (see MN 101:23.2).

sn35.29:1.5.eng: And what is the all that is overcome?

sn35.29:1.6.pli: Cakkhu, bhikkhave, addhabhūtaṃ, rūpā addhabhūtā, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ addhabhūtaṃ, cakkhusamphasso addhabhūto, yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi addhabhūtaṃ.
sn35.29:1.6.eng: The eye is overcome. Sights are overcome. Eye consciousness is overcome. Eye contact is overcome. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact is also overcome.

sn35.29:1.8.pli: ‘Jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi addhabhūtan’ti vadāmi …pe…
sn35.29:1.8.eng: Overcome by the fires of greed, hate, and delusion. Overcome by rebirth, old age, and death, by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress, I say.

sn35.29:1.9.pli: jivhā addhabhūtā, rasā addhabhūtā, jivhāviññāṇaṃ addhabhūtaṃ, jivhāsamphasso addhabhūto, yampidaṃ jivhāsamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi addhabhūtaṃ.

sn35.29:1.11.pli: ‘Jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi addhabhūtan’ti vadāmi.

sn35.29:1.13.pli: mano addhabhūto, dhammā addhabhūtā, manoviññāṇaṃ addhabhūtaṃ, manosamphasso addhabhūto, yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi addhabhūtaṃ.
sn35.29:1.13.eng: mind is overcome. Ideas are overcome. Mind consciousness is overcome. Mind contact is overcome. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also overcome.

sn35.29:1.15.pli: ‘Jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi addhabhūtan’ti vadāmi.
sn35.29:1.15.eng: Overcome by greed, hate, and delusion. Overcome by rebirth, old age, and death, by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress, I say.

sn35.29:1.16.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati, rūpesupi nibbindati, cakkhuviññāṇepi nibbindati, cakkhusamphassepi nibbindati …pe…
sn35.29:1.16.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact. And they grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact.

sn35.29:1.17.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tasmimpi nibbindati.
sn35.29:1.17.eng: They grow disillusioned with the ear … nose … tongue … body … mind … painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact.

sn35.29:1.18.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati, virāgā vimuccati, vimuttasmiṃ ‘vimuttam’iti ñāṇaṃ hoti,
sn35.29:1.18.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn35.29:1.19.pli: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn35.29:1.19.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn35.3:1.2.pli: Yadanattā taṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn35.3:1.2.eng: And what’s not-self should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn35.3:1.8.pli: Yadanattā taṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn35.3:1.8.eng: And what’s not-self should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn35.3:1.10.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”
